# Draft:Canberra historical bus stops

References
Introduction
The city of Canberra has a rich heritage of public transport infrastructure, and among these the historical bus-stops and shelters form a distinctive part of the urban fabric. This article explores the development, design and legacy of these stops — including the iconic cylindrical cycle concrete-shelters — and how they reflect broader changes in public transport in the Australian Capital Territory (ACT).
Background & Context
Public bus services in Canberra began in the early 20th century as the city expanded beyond its initial core. According to one study, Vancouver-style suburban expansion and new suburbs from the 1950s to 1970s increased the need for more bus stops and shelters.

The Canberra Times
+2
Over time, as bus network planning matured under Australian Capital Territory Internal Omnibus Network (ACTION) and the National Capital Development Commission (NCDC), purpose-built bus shelters and interchanges were introduced.
Iconic Concrete Bus Shelters
Design & Origins
One of the most recognisable features of Canberra’s bus-stop history are the concrete cylindrical bus shelters designed by architect Clem Cummings in 1974 for the NCDC.
This is Canberra
+1
These shelters are characterised by:
A cylindrical concrete shell
Fibreglass window frames and Lexan windows (although many later lost their windows)
Goulburn Mulwaree Council
+1
A fibreglass bench inside
Paint-scheme of cream exterior with orange bench/window frames
Wikipedia
They began installation in May 1975, with the first Series I shelters (about 95 of them) rolled out.
Capital history here
+1
Significance & Legacy
These bus shelters have earned iconic status among Canberrans. A 2022 article described them as “to Canberra what the red telephone box is to London”.
This is Canberra
Their significance arises from:
Their design reflecting a period of Canberra’s development — the 1970s, when urban expansion, public transport and modernist architecture intersected.
Capital history here
+1
Their durability and continuing presence (many remain in situ).
Wikipedia
Their cultural resonance: they’ve appeared in art, merchandise, and local nostalgia.
This is Canberra
Challenges & Changes
Over the decades:
The Lexan windows proved vulnerable to vandalism; many shelters ended up missing windows or glass.
Wikipedia
+1
Lighting was never installed originally; only in recent years has solar-powered lighting been trialled.
Wikipedia
Accessibility requirements changed the design and replacement of bus stops in newer suburbs.
This is Canberra
Key Historical Bus Interchanges & Stops
City Interchange (Civic)
City Interchange (formerly City Bus Station) is located on Alinga Street, Civic.
Wikipedia
Opened: 23 November 1982, replacing temporary bus stop arrangements.
Wikipedia
Significance: It marked a shift from buses simply stopping on general traffic streets to a dedicated interchange facility.
Legacy: It remains a major hub for Transport Canberra services.
Wikipedia
Woden Interchange
Woden Interchange (formerly Woden bus station) opened 4 December 1972 in Woden Town Centre.
Wikipedia
+1
From the 1980s onwards it underwent upgrades (1982, 1994) to enlarge and modernise the facility.
Wikipedia
In January 2023 it closed, to be replaced by a new interchange as part of the light-rail integration.
Region Canberra
Significance: Among the early purpose-built suburban bus stations in Australia, reflecting the growth of Woden as a satellite centre.
Tuggeranong Interchange
Tuggeranong Interchange opened 9 August 1991 in the Tuggeranong Town Centre.
Wikipedia
It replaced earlier simpler bus stops to provide a proper interchange for that district.
Decommissioned Stops & Network Changes
Historically many bus stops in suburban areas of the ACT have been decommissioned or repurposed, especially after the 2019 Integrated Public Transport Network and the introduction of light-rail.
For example, as of October 2023, a question to the ACT Legislative Assembly listed numerous stop-IDs that had ceased use since 2016, citing reasons such as service integration and light rail construction.
questions.parliament.act.gov.au
Heritage Considerations & Cultural Value
The concrete bus shelters are being considered for heritage recognition by the ACT Heritage Council given their architectural and cultural significance.
This is Canberra
+1
They serve as physical reminders of changes in urban transport planning, suburban expansion, and architectural styles.
Challenges for the Future
Many older shelters are now missing original windows or have been modified, reducing their heritage integrity.
As transport networks modernise (with electric buses, light-rail, digital displays), there is tension between preserving heritage stops and upgrading for accessibility, safety and usability.
Some former bus stops and shelters now serve other purposes (e.g., art installations, community uses).
Summary
The historical bus stops of Canberra — from the cylindrical concrete shelters of the 1970s to the major interchanges of Woden and Tuggeranong — reflect not only the practical growth of public transport infrastructure but also wider trends in architecture, urban design and community identity. While many remain in active service and are valued by residents, others have been retired or replaced, leaving a legacy that is worthy of documentation and preservation.
